content.question: Donald believes that western commuters drive an average of 10 miles more per day than eastern commuters do. He selects random samples from each group. The western mean is 23.5 miles, and the eastern mean is 19.4 miles. A 95 percent confidence interval to estimate the difference in population means, in miles, is <math alttext="open parenthesis, 2.5 comma 5.7, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mn>2.5</mn></mrow><mo>,</mo><mrow><mn>5.7</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>. Which of the following statements is supported by the interval?

choices.label: The probability that Donald is correct is 0.05 because 10 is not contained in the interval.
The probability that Donald is correct is 0.95 because 10 is not contained in the interval.

Donald is likely to be correct because the difference in the sample means <math alttext="open parenthesis, 23.5 minus 19.4 equals 4.1, close parenthesis " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>23.5</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>19.4</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>4.1</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is contained in the interval.
Donald is likely to be incorrect because 10 is not contained in the interval.

Donald is likely to be incorrect because the difference in the sample means was <math alttext="23.5 minus 19.4 equals 4.1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>23.5</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>19.4</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>4.1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> miles.

content.answer: Donald is likely to be incorrect because 10 is not contained in the interval.

topic.text: 7.7: Justifying a Claim About the Difference of Two Means Based on a Confidence Interval

skill.text: Skill 4.D: Justify a claim based on a confidence interval.
